entry.title: Combined summary - Swift Activation - CTV
entry.summary:
The discourse among Bitcoin developers regarding the activation of CheckTemplateVerify (CTV) reflects a community at crossroads, deliberating on the readiness and potential benefits of implementing this feature. The conversation highlights that despite some developers' eagerness to use payment pools enabled by CTV, there is a consensus that more work is required before activation. It is noted that current proof of concepts (PoCs) haven't addressed significant real-world issues on the mainnet, prompting a bounty program offering 0.01 to 1 BTC for the development of impactful PoCs. This initiative can be explored further through a dedicated link.
The dialogue suggests there is misalignment within the developer community, with some believing that TXHASH resolves all concerns, while others call for thorough reviews and tests. Additionally, the lack of clarity on the activation method for CTV and the perception of an aggressive timeline has led to calls for patience and a proposed delay of two years for its activation. Amid these discussions, contributions by _reardencode_ are acknowledged as potentially beneficial for CTV and covenants in general.
In another aspect of the debate, frustration is expressed over the insufficient backing for a BIP 8 client configured with 'LOCKINONTIMEOUT' set to true. The author of the email has already established a branch which can be accessed online, emphasizing the need for open discussion on activation methods and the importance of offering users options without being perceived as confrontational. This sentiment underscores the desire for a collaborative approach to BIP activation and user empowerment.
Luke's input adds a layer of contention, as he opposes what he views as a deceptive proposal that fails to truly activate CTV but instead gives miners the option to do so. He warns against running the update and advocates for preparedness to implement a User-Activated Soft Fork (URSF) if necessary, to enforce rules against blocks signaling for the controversial update. This sense of urgency indicates deep divisions over network updates and concerns about autonomy and control within the Bitcoin ecosystem.
Finally, the email details modifications to CTV activation parameters designed to reflect simplicity and practicality. These adjustments include setting specific start times, timeouts, and minimum activation heights without introducing novel mechanisms. The sender touts CTV as a straightforward covenant proposal that supports features like payment pools, vaults, and congestion control. They emphasize the significance of the upcoming client build deadline of January 1, 2024, warning that missing it could lead to protracted debates and potential delays until 2028. Communication is closed by highlighting secure email practices, indicative of the importance placed on confidentiality and security within these exchanges.
